{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{About|the U.S. Government documents|the 2003 film|The Pentagon Papers (film)}} {{italic title}} [[File:Dissident Activities in Indochina.svg|thumb|A CIA map of dissident activities in Indochina, published as part of the ''Pentagon Papers'']] The '''''Pentagon Papers''''', officially titled '''''Report of the Office of the Secretary of Defense Vietnam Task Force''''', is a [[United States Department of Defense]] history of the United States' political and military involvement in [[Vietnam]] from 1945 to 1967. The papers were released by [[Daniel Ellsberg]], who had worked on the study; they were first brought to the attention of the public on the front page of ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 1971.{{cite news| title=The Pentagon Papers|publisher=[[United Press International|United Press International (UPI)]]|year=1971|url=http://www.upi.com/Audio/Year_in_Review/Events-of-1971/The-Pentagon-Papers/12295509436546-7/|accessdate=2010-07-02}}{{Cite news|last=Sheehan|first=Neil|authorlink=Neil Sheehan|title=Vietnam Archive: Pentagon Study Traces 3 Decades of Growing U.S. Involvement|newspaper= The New York Times|date=1971-06-13|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/06/13/archives/vietnam-archive-pentagon-study-traces-3-decades-of-growing-u-s.html|accessdate=2015-08-03}} A 1996 article in ''The New York Times'' said that the ''Pentagon Papers'' had demonstrated, among other things, that the [[Presidency of Lyndon B. Johnson|Johnson Administration]] "systematically lied, not only to the public but also to Congress".{{Cite news|last=Apple|first=R.W.|authorlink=R. W. Apple, Jr.|title=25 Years Later;Lessons From the Pentagon Papers|newspaper= The New York Times|date=1996-06-23|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/23/weekinreview/25-years-later-lessons-from-the-pentagon-papers.html|accessdate=2013-10-23}} More specifically, the papers revealed that the U.S. had secretly enlarged the scope of its actions in the [[Vietnam War]] with the [[Operation Menu|bombings]] of nearby [[Cambodia]] and [[Laos]], coastal raids on [[North Vietnam]], and [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] attacks, none of which were reported in the mainstream media. For his disclosure of the ''Pentagon Papers'', Ellsberg was initially charged with conspiracy, espionage, and theft of government property, but the charges were later dismissed after prosecutors investigating the [[Watergate scandal]] discovered that the staff members in the [[Nixon White House]] had ordered the so-called [[White House Plumbers]] to engage in unlawful efforts to discredit Ellsberg.{{cite news|title=The Watergate Story|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/watergate/timeline.html|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=October 26, 2013|quote=Watergate prosecutors find a memo addressed to [[John Ehrlichman]] describing in detail the plans to burglarize the office of Pentagon Papers defendant Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatrist, ''The Post'' reports.}}{{cite news |url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/learning/general/onthisday/big/0511.html |title=Pentagon Papers Charges Are Dismissed; Judge Byrne Frees Ellsberg and Russo, Assails 'Improper Government Conduct' |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 11, 1973 |accessdate=2018-11-04}} In June 2011, the entirety of the ''Pentagon Papers'' was declassified and publicly released.{{cite web|title=Pentagon Papers|url=http://www.history.com/topics/pentagon-papers|publisher=[[History (U.S. TV channel)]]|accessdate=October 26, 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/06/13/137150344/after-40-years-pentagon-papers-declassified-in-full |title=After 40 Years, Pentagon Papers Declassified In Full |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=2018-11-04}} == Contents == [[File:Ime Magazine Pentagon Papers.jpg|thumb|Shortly after their release in June 1971, the ''Pentagon Papers'' were featured on the cover of [[Time (magazine)|''TIME'' magazine]] for revealing "The Secret War" of the United States in Vietnam.]] [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert McNamara]] created the Vietnam Study Task Force on June 17, 1967, for the purpose of writing an "encyclopedic history of the [[Vietnam War]]". McNamara claimed that he wanted to leave a written record for historians, to prevent policy errors in future administrations.{{harvnb|McNamara|1996|p=256}} McNamara neglected to inform either President [[Lyndon Johnson]] or Secretary of State [[Dean Rusk]] about the study. One report claimed that McNamara planned to give the work to his friend [[Robert F. Kennedy]], who sought the [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 1968|Democratic presidential nomination in 1968]].{{harvnb|McNamara|1996|p=282}} McNamara later denied this, although he admitted that he should have informed Johnson and Rusk. Instead of using existing Defense Department historians, McNamara assigned his close aide and [[Assistant Secretary of Defense]] [[John T. McNaughton]] to collect the papers.{{harvnb|McNamara|1996|p=280}} McNaughton died in a [[Piedmont Airlines Flight 22|plane crash]] one month after work began in June 1967, but the project continued under the direction of Defense Department official [[Leslie H. Gelb]]. Thirty-six analysts—half of them active-duty military officers, the rest academics and civilian federal employees—worked on the study. The analysts largely used existing files in the [[Office of the Secretary of Defense]]. In order to keep the study secret from others, including [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] [[Walt W. Rostow]], they conducted no interviews or consultations with the armed forces, with the White House, or with other federal agencies. McNamara left the Defense Department in February 1968, and his successor [[Clark M. Clifford]] received the finished study on January 15, 1969, five days before [[Richard Nixon]]'s inauguration, although Clifford claimed he never read it. The study consisted of 3,000 pages of historical analysis and 4,000 pages of original government documents in 47 volumes, and was classified as "Top Secret – Sensitive". ("Sensitive" is not an [[Classified information in the United States|official security designation]]; it meant that access to the study should be controlled.) The task force published 15 copies; the think tank [[RAND Corporation]] received two of the copies from Gelb, [[Morton Halperin]] and [[Paul Warnke]], with access granted if at least two of the three approved.{{cite magazine |last=Correll |first=John T. |url=http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/February%202007/0207pentagon.aspx |title=The Pentagon Papers |format= |work=Air Force Magazine |date=February 2007|accessdate=2018-11-04}}{{cite magazine |last=Correll |first=John T. |url=http://www.airforcemag.com/MagazineArchive/Documents/2007/February%202007/0207pentagon.pdf |title=The Pentagon Papers |format=pdf |work=Air Force Magazine |date=February 2007|accessdate=2018-11-04}} === Actual objective of the Vietnam War: Containment of China === {{Main|China containment policy}} [[File:Containment of China.jpg|700px|thumb|As laid out by U.S. Secretary of Defense [[Robert McNamara]], the [[China containment policy|Chinese containment policy]] of the United States was a long-run strategic effort to surround [[Beijing]] with the [[Soviet Union|USSR]], its [[satellite state]]s, as well as:
a) The [[Japan]]–[[Korea]] front,
b) The [[India]]–[[Pakistan]] front, and
c) The [[Southeast Asia]] front]] Although President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] stated that the aim of the Vietnam War was to secure an "independent, non-Communist [[South Vietnam]]", a January 1965 memorandum by Secretary of Defense [[Robert McNamara]] stated that an underlying justification was "not to help a friend, but to contain China".{{cite web|title=COVER STORY: Pentagon Papers: The Secret War|url=http://edition.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1996/analysis/back.time/9606/28/index.shtml|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=June 28, 1971|accessdate=October 26, 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://content.time.com/time/subscriber/printout/0,8816,905234,00.html |title=The Nation: Pentagon Papers: The Secret War |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=June 28, 1971 |accessdate=2018-11-04}} On November 3, 1965, McNamara sent a memorandum to President Johnson, in which he explained the "major policy decisions with respect to our course of action in Vietnam". The memorandum begins by disclosing the rationale behind the bombing of North Vietnam in February 1965: {{quote|The February decision to bomb North Vietnam and the July approval of Phase I deployments make sense only if they are in support of a long-run United States policy to contain [[China]].{{cite web|last=[[Robert McNamara]]|title=Draft Memorandum From Secretary of Defense McNamara to President Johnson|url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1964-68v03/d189|publisher=[[Office of the Historian]]|date=November 3, 1965}}}} McNamara accused China of harboring [[imperialism|imperial]] aspirations like those of [[Nazi Germany]] and [[Imperial Japan]]. According to McNamara, the Chinese were conspiring to "organize all of Asia" against the United States: {{quote|China—like Germany in 1917, like Germany in the West and Japan in the East in the late 30s, and like the USSR in 1947—looms as a major power threatening to undercut our importance and effectiveness in the world and, more remotely but more menacingly, to organize all of Asia against us.}} To encircle the Chinese, the United States aimed to establish "three fronts" as part of a "long-run effort to contain China": {{quote|There are three fronts to a long-run effort to contain China (realizing that the USSR "contains" China on the north and northwest): (a) the Japan–Korea front; (b) the India–Pakistan front; and (c) the [[Southeast Asia]] front.}} However, McNamara admitted that the [[China containment policy|containment of China]] would ultimately sacrifice a significant amount of America's time, money and lives. === Internal affairs of Vietnam === {|class="infobox bordered" style="font-size:95%; width:25em;" ! style="font-size:120%; text-align:center; padding:5px 0;" | '''Timeline''' |- | * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|1950|}}''' |event= The United States provided large-scale military equipment to the French in its fight against the [[communist]] [[Viet Minh]]}} * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|1954|}}''' |event= The United States began to engage in "acts of sabotage and terror warfare" in the defense of South Vietnam against communist North Vietnam}} * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date| 1955|}}''' |event= The United States encouraged and directly assisted South Vietnamese President [[Ngô Đình Diệm]]'s rise to power}} * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date| 1963|}}''' |event= The United States encouraged and directly assisted the overthrow of the South Vietnamese President Ngô Đình Diệm}} * {{Timeline-event |date='''{{Start date|1964|08|02}}''' |event= Following the [[Gulf of Tonkin incident]], the United States manipulated public opinion in its preparation for open warfare against a [[communist]] takeover of South Vietnam }} |} Years before the August 2, 1964 [[Gulf of Tonkin incident]] occurred, the U.S. government was indirectly or directly involved in Vietnam's affairs: * Under President [[Harry S. Truman]], the U.S. government aided [[French Indochina|France]] in its war against the communist-led [[Viet Minh]] during the [[First Indochina War]].{{cite news|last=Sheehan|first=Neil|authorlink=Neil Sheehan|title=Vietnam Archive: Pentagon Study Traces 3 Decades of Growing U.S. Involvement|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/04/13/reviews/papers-overview.html|work=The New York Times|date=June 13, 1971}} * Under President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], the U.S. government played a "direct role in the ultimate breakdown of the [[Geneva Conference (1954)|Geneva settlement]]" in 1954 by supporting the fledgling South Vietnam and covertly undermining the communist country of North Vietnam. * Under President [[John F. Kennedy]], the U.S. government transformed its policy towards Vietnam from a limited "gamble" to a broad "commitment". * Under President Lyndon B. Johnson, the U.S. government began waging covert military operations against communist North Vietnam in defense of South Vietnam. ==== Role of the United States in the rise of President Diem ==== [[File:Ngo Dinh Diem at Washington - ARC 542189.jpg|thumb|right|U.S. President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] greets South Vietnam's President [[Ngo Dinh Diem]], whose rise to power was backed by the United States, according to the ''Pentagon Papers'']] In a section of the ''Pentagon Papers'' titled "Kennedy Commitments and Programs," America's commitment to [[South Vietnam]] was attributed to the creation of the country by the United States. As acknowledged by the papers: {{quote|We must note that South Vietnam (unlike any of the other countries in Southeast Asia) was essentially the creation of the United States.{{cite web|title=Evolution of the War. Counterinsurgency: The Kennedy Commitments and Programs, 1961|url=http://media.nara.gov/research/pentagon-papers/Pentagon-Papers-Part-IV-B-1.pdf|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|accessdate=October 28, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809120534/http://media.nara.gov/research/pentagon-papers/Pentagon-Papers-Part-IV-B-1.pdf|archive-date=August 9, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} }} In a sub-section titled "Special American Commitment to Vietnam", the papers emphasized once again the role played by the United States: {{quote | * "Without U.S. support [[Ngo Dinh Diem|[Ngo Dinh] Diem]] almost certainly could not have consolidated his hold on the South during 1955 and 1956." * "Without the threat of U.S. intervention, South Vietnam could not have refused to even discuss the elections called for in 1956 under the Geneva settlement without being immediately overrun by the Viet Minh armies." * "Without U.S. aid in the years following, the Diem regime certainly, and an independent South Vietnam almost as certainly, could not have survived".}} More specifically, the United States sent US$28.4 million worth of equipment and supplies to help the Diem regime strengthen its army. In addition, 32,000 men from [[South Vietnamese Popular Force|South Vietnam's Civil Guard]] were trained by the United States at a cost of US$12.7 million. It was hoped that Diem's regime, after receiving a significant amount of U.S. assistance, would be able to withstand the [[Viet Cong]]. The papers identified General [[Edward Lansdale]], who served in the [[Office of Strategic Services]] (OSS) and worked for the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA), as a "key figure" in the establishment of Ngo Dinh Diem as the President of South Vietnam, and the backing of Diem's regime thereafter. As written by Lansdale in a 1961 memorandum: "We (the U.S.) must support Ngo Dinh Diem until another strong executive can replace him legally." ==== Role of the United States in the overthrow of Diem's regime ==== [[File:Corpse of Ngô Đình Diệm in the 1963 coup.jpg|The body of President Diệm after he was assassinated in the [[1963 South Vietnamese coup]], which was backed by the United States government|right|thumb|200px]] According to the ''Pentagon Papers'', the U.S. government played a key role in the [[1963 South Vietnamese coup]], in which President Ngo Dinh Diem was assassinated. While maintaining "clandestine contact" with Vietnamese generals planning a coup, the U.S. cut off its aid to President Diem and openly supported a successor government in what the authors called an "essentially leaderless Vietnam": {{quote|For the military [[coup d'etat]] against Ngo Dinh Diem, the U.S. must accept its full share of responsibility. Beginning in August 1963 we variously authorized, sanctioned and encouraged the coup efforts of the Vietnamese generals and offered full support for a successor government. In October we cut off aid to Diem in a direct rebuff, giving a green light to the generals. We maintained clandestine contact with them throughout the planning and execution of the coup and sought to review their operational plans and proposed new government. Thus, as the nine-year rule of Diem came to a bloody end, our complicity in his overthrow heightened our responsibilities and our commitment in an essentially leaderless Vietnam.{{cite web |url=http://media.nara.gov/research/pentagon-papers/Pentagon-Papers-Part-IV-B-5.pdf |title=The Pentagon Papers, Vol. 2, Chapter 4, "The Overthrow of Ngo Dinh Diem, May-November, 1963" |publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]] |date= |accessdate=2013-10-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130809132314/http://media.nara.gov/research/pentagon-papers/Pentagon-Papers-Part-IV-B-5.pdf |archive-date=2013-08-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}}} As early as August 23, 1963, an unnamed U.S. representative had met with Vietnamese generals planning a coup against President Diem. According to ''The New York Times'', this U.S. representative was later identified to be CIA agent [[Lucien Conein]].{{cite news|author=Tim Weiner|title=Lucien Conein, 79, Legendary Cold War Spy|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/06/07/world/lucien-conein-79-legendary-cold-war-spy.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 7, 1998|quote=He ran agents behind the Iron Curtain in the early 1950's. He was the C.I.A.'s contact with friendly generals in Vietnam as the long war took shape there. He was the man through whom the United States gave the generals tacit approval as they planned the assassination of South Vietnam's President, Ngo Dinh Diem, in November 1963.}} === Proposed operations === The [[Director of Central Intelligence]], [[John A. McCone]], proposed the following categories of military action: * Category 1 – Air raids on major [[Viet Cong]] supply centers, conducted simultaneously by [[Republic of Vietnam Air Force|South Vietnam's air force]] and the United States Air Force (codenamed [[Farm Gate (military operation)|Farmgate]]){{cite web|last=John A. McCone|title=Probable Communist Reactions to Certain US or US-Sponsored Courses of Action in Vietnam and Laos|url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1964-68v01/d253|publisher=[[Office of the Historian]]|accessdate=October 26, 2013|date=July 28, 1964}} * Category 2 – Cross-border raids on major [[Viet Cong]] supply centers, conducted by South Vietnamese units and US military advisors. * Category 3 – Limited air strikes on North Vietnamese targets by unmarked planes flown exclusively by non-US aircrews. However, McCone did not believe these military actions alone could lead to an escalation of the situation because the "fear of escalation would probably restrain the Communists". In a memorandum addressed to President [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Johnson]] on July 28, 1964, McCone explained: {{quote|In response to the first or second categories of action, local Communist military forces in the areas of actual attack would react vigorously, but we believe that none of the Communist powers involved would respond with major military moves designed to change the nature of the conflict... Air strikes on North Vietnam itself (Category 3) would evoke sharper Communist reactions than air strikes confined to targets in Laos, but even in this case fear of escalation would probably restrain the Communists from a major military response...}} Barely a month after the Gulf of Tonkin incident on August 2, 1964, National Security Advisor [[McGeorge Bundy]] warned that further provocations should not be undertaken until October, when the government of South Vietnam (GVN) would become fully prepared for a full-scale war against North Vietnam. In a memorandum addressed to President Johnson on September 8, 1964, Bundy wrote: {{quote|The main further question is the extent to which we should add elements to the above actions that would tend deliberately to provoke a [[North Vietnam|DRV]] reaction, and consequent retaliation by us. Examples of actions to be considered were running US naval patrols increasingly close to the North Vietnamese coast and/or [''[[sic]]''] associating them with [[Operation 34A|34A operations]]. We believe such deliberately provocative elements should not be added in the immediate future while the GVN is still struggling to its feet. By early October, however, we may recommend such actions depending on GVN progress and Communist reaction in the meantime, especially to US naval patrols.{{cite web|last=[[McGeorge Bundy]]|title=Courses of action for South Vietnam|url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1964-68v01/d342|publisher=[[Office of the Historian]]|accessdate=October 26, 2013|date=September 8, 1964}}}} While maritime operations played a key role in the provocation of North Vietnam, U.S. military officials had initially proposed to fly a [[Lockheed U-2]] reconnaissance aircraft over the country, but this was to be replaced by other plans. ==Leak== Daniel Ellsberg knew the leaders of the task force well. He had worked as an aide to McNaughton from 1964 to 1965, had worked on the study for several months in 1967, and Gelb and Halperin approved his access to the work at RAND in 1969.{{r|correll200702}} Now opposing the war, Ellsberg and his friend [[Anthony Russo (whistleblower)|Anthony Russo]]{{cite web | url=http://www.antiwar.com/blog/2008/08/07/ellsberg-remembering-anthony-russo/ | title=Ellsberg: Remembering Anthony Russo | publisher=Antiwar.com | date=2008-08-07 | accessdate=April 17, 2011 | last=Ellsberg |first=Daniel}} photocopied the study in October 1969 intending to disclose it. Ellsberg approached Nixon's National Security Advisor [[Henry Kissinger]], Senators [[William Fulbright]] and [[George McGovern]], and others, but none were interested. In February 1971, Ellsberg discussed the study with ''The New York Times'' reporter [[Neil Sheehan]], and gave 43 of the volumes to him in March. Before publication, ''The New York Times'' sought legal advice. The paper's regular outside counsel, [[Lord Day & Lord]], advised against publication, but in-house counsel [[James Goodale]] prevailed with his argument that the press had a [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] right to publish information significant to the people's understanding of their government's policy. ''The New York Times'' began publishing excerpts on June 13, 1971; the first article in the series was titled "Vietnam Archive: Pentagon Study Traces Three Decades of Growing US Involvement". The study was dubbed ''The Pentagon Papers'' during the resulting media publicity.{{cite web|title=Introduction to the Court Opinion on The New York Times Co. v. United States Case|url=http://usinfo.state.gov/usa/infousa/facts/democrac/48.htm|accessdate=2005-12-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051204121721/https://usinfo.state.gov/usa/infousa/facts/democrac/48.htm|archivedate=2005-12-04|df=}} Street protests, political controversy, and lawsuits followed. To ensure the possibility of public debate about the papers' content, on June 29, [[United States Senate|US Senator]] [[Mike Gravel]], an Alaska Democrat, entered 4,100 pages of the papers into the record of his Subcommittee on Public Buildings and Grounds. These portions of the papers, which were edited for Gravel by [[Howard Zinn]] and [[Noam Chomsky]], were subsequently published by [[Beacon Press]], the publishing arm of the [[Unitarian Universalist Association]] of Congregations.{{cite web|title=The Pentagon Papers, Senator Mike Gravel edition, Beacon Press|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/248181?tab=editions}} A federal [[grand jury]] was subsequently empaneled to investigate possible violations of federal law in the release of the report. Leonard Rodberg, a Gravel aide, was [[subpoena]]ed to testify about his role in obtaining and arranging for publication of the ''Pentagon Papers''. Gravel asked the court (in ''[[Gravel v. United States]]'') to quash the subpoena on the basis of the [[Speech or Debate Clause]] in [[Article One of the United States Constitution|Article I, Section 6]] of the [[United States Constitution]]. That clause provides that "for any Speech or Debate in either House, [a Senator or Representative] shall not be questioned in any other Place", meaning that Gravel could not be prosecuted for anything said on the Senate floor, and, by extension, for anything entered to the ''Congressional Record'', allowing the papers to be publicly read without threat of a [[treason]] trial and conviction. When Gravel's request was reviewed by the U.S. Supreme Court, the Court denied the request to extend this protection to Gravel or his legislative aide, Leonard Rodberg, because the grand jury subpoena served on them related to a third party rather than any act they themselves committed for the preparation of materials later entered into the Congressional Record. Nevertheless, the grand jury investigation was halted, and the publication of the papers was never prosecuted. Later, Ellsberg said the documents "demonstrated unconstitutional behavior by a succession of presidents, the violation of their oath and the violation of the oath of every one of their subordinates."{{cite web |url=http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=07/07/02/1331255 |title=How the ''Pentagon Papers'' Came to be Published by the Beacon Press: A Remarkable Story Told by Whistleblower Daniel Ellsberg, Dem Presidential Candidate Mike Gravel and Unitarian Leader Robert West |publisher=[[Democracy Now!]] |date= |accessdate=2013-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703224833/http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=07%2F07%2F02%2F1331255 |archivedate=2007-07-03 |df= }} He added that he leaked the Papers to end what he perceived to be "a wrongful war." === The Nixon administration's restraint of the media === President Nixon at first planned to do nothing about publication of the study since it embarrassed the Johnson and Kennedy administrations rather than his. But Henry Kissinger convinced the president that not opposing the publication set a negative precedent for future secrets. The administration argued Ellsberg and Russo were guilty of a [[felony]] under the [[Espionage Act of 1917]], because they had no authority to publish classified documents.{{cite web|title=The Pentagon Papers Case|url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB48/nixon.html|accessdate=2005-12-05}} After failing to persuade ''The New York Times'' to voluntarily cease publication on June 14, [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[John N. Mitchell]] and Nixon obtained a federal court injunction forcing ''The New York Times'' to cease publication after three articles. ''The New York Times'' publisher [[Arthur Ochs Sulzberger]] said: {{quote|Newspapers, as our editorial said this morning, we're really a part of history that should have been made available, considerably longer ago. I just didn't feel there was any breach of national security, in the sense that we were giving secrets to the enemy.}} The newspaper appealed the injunction, and the case ''[[New York Times Co. v. United States]]'' (403 U.S. 713) quickly rose through the U.S. legal system to the [[United States Supreme Court|Supreme Court]].{{cite web|title=New York Times Co. v. United States, 403 U.S. 713 (1971)|url=http://supct.law.cornell.edu/supct/cases/403us713.htm|accessdate=2005-12-05}} On June 18, 1971, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' began publishing its own series of articles based upon the ''Pentagon Papers''; Ellsberg had given portions to ''The Washington Post'' reporter [[Ben Bagdikian]]. Bagdikian brought the information to editor [[Ben Bradlee]]. That day, Assistant U.S. Attorney General [[William Rehnquist]] asked ''The Washington Post'' to cease publication. After the paper refused, Rehnquist sought an injunction in U.S. district court. Judge [[Murray Gurfein]] declined to issue such an injunction, writing that "[t]he security of the Nation is not at the ramparts alone. Security also lies in the value of our free institutions. A cantankerous press, an obstinate press, a ubiquitous press must be suffered by those in authority to preserve the even greater values of freedom of expression and the right of the people to know."''[[United States v. N.Y. Times Co.]]'', 328 F. Supp. 324, 331 (S.D.N.Y. 1971). The government appealed that decision, and on June 26 the Supreme Court agreed to hear it jointly with ''The New York Times'' case. Fifteen other newspapers received copies of the study and began publishing it. === The Supreme Court allows further publication === {{Main|New York Times Co. v. United States}} On June 30, 1971, the Supreme Court decided, 6–3, that the government failed to meet the heavy [[Legal burden of proof|burden of proof]] required for [[prior restraint]] injunction. The nine justices wrote nine opinions disagreeing on significant, substantive matters. {{quote|Only a free and unrestrained press can effectively expose deception in government. And paramount among the responsibilities of a free press is the duty to prevent any part of the government from deceiving the people and sending them off to distant lands to die of foreign fevers and foreign shot and shell.|Justice Black{{cite web|title=NEW YORK TIMES CO. v. UNITED STATES, 403 U.S. 713 (1971)|url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=US&vol=403&invol=713}}}} Thomas Tedford and Dale Herbeck summarized the reaction of editors and journalists at the time: {{quote|As the press rooms of the ''Times'' and the ''Post'' began to hum to the lifting of the censorship order, the journalists of America pondered with grave concern the fact that for fifteen days the 'free press' of the nation had been prevented from publishing an important document and for their troubles had been given an inconclusive and uninspiring 'burden-of-proof' decision by a sharply divided Supreme Court. There was relief, but no great rejoicing, in the editorial offices of America's publishers and broadcasters.|Tedford and Herbeck, pp. 225–226.{{cite web|title=Tedford & Herbeck, Freedom of Speech in the United States, 5 ed.|url=http://www.stratapub.com/TedfordHerbeck/tedford_&_herbeck_freedom_of_speech_in_the_united_states.htm|accessdate=2005-12-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051202043033/http://www.stratapub.com/TedfordHerbeck/tedford_%26_herbeck_freedom_of_speech_in_the_united_states.htm|archive-date=2005-12-02|dead-url=yes|df=}}}} === Legal charges against Ellsberg === Ellsberg surrendered to authorities in Boston, and admitted that he had given the papers to the press: "I felt that as an American citizen, as a responsible citizen, I could no longer cooperate in concealing this information from the American public. I did this clearly at my own jeopardy and I am prepared to answer to all the consequences of this decision". He was indicted by a grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of stealing and holding secret documents.[https://www.upi.com/Archives/Audio/Events-of-1971/The-Pentagon-Papers/ The Pentagon Papers] 1971 Year in Review, UPI Federal District Judge [[William Matthew Byrne, Jr.]] declared a [[mistrial (law)|mistrial]] and dismissed all charges against Ellsberg and Russo on May 11, 1973, after it was revealed that: agents acting on the orders of the Nixon administration illegally broke into the office of Ellsberg's psychiatrist and attempted to steal files; representatives of the Nixon administration approached the Ellsberg trial judge with an offer of the job of FBI directorship; several irregularities appeared in the government's case including its claim that it had lost records of illegal wiretapping against Ellsberg conducted by the [[White House Plumbers]] in the contemporaneous [[Watergate scandal]]. Byrne ruled: "The totality of the circumstances of this case which I have only briefly sketched offend a sense of justice. The bizarre events have incurably infected the prosecution of this case." Ellsberg and Russo were freed due to the mistrial; they were not acquitted of violating the Espionage Act. In March 1972, political scientist [[Samuel L. Popkin]], then assistant professor of Government at [[Harvard University]], was jailed for a week for his refusal to answer questions before a grand jury investigating the Pentagon Papers case, during a hearing before the [[Boston]] [[Federal District Court]]. The Faculty Council later passed a resolution condemning the government's interrogation of scholars on the grounds that "an unlimited right of grand juries to ask any question and to expose a witness to citations for contempt could easily threaten scholarly research".Meislin, Richard J. [https://archive.is/20130204085944/http://theharvardcrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=495202 Popkin Faces Jail Sentence In Contempt of Court Case], ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]'', March 22, 1972. Gelb estimated that ''The New York Times'' only published about five percent of the study's 7,000 pages. The Beacon Press edition was also incomplete. Halperin, who had originally classified the study as secret, obtained most of the unpublished portions under the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]] and the [[University of Texas]] published them in 1983. The [[National Security Archive]] published the remaining portions in 2002. The study itself remained formally classified until 2011. == Impact == The ''Pentagon Papers'' revealed that the United States had expanded its war with the bombing of Cambodia and Laos, coastal raids on North Vietnam, and Marine Corps attacks, none of which had been reported by the American media.{{cite book|title=How We Got Here: The '70s|last=Frum|first=David|authorlink=David Frum|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York, New York|isbn=0-465-04195-7|page=43}} The most damaging revelations in the papers revealed that four administrations (Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, and Johnson), had misled the public regarding their intentions. For example, the Eisenhower administration actively worked against the [[1954 Geneva Conference|Geneva Accords]]. The John F. Kennedy administration knew of plans to overthrow South Vietnamese leader Ngo Dinh Diem before his death in a [[1963 South Vietnamese coup|November 1963 coup]]. President Johnson had decided to expand the war while promising "we seek no wider war" during his 1964 presidential campaign, including plans to bomb North Vietnam well before the [[United States presidential election, 1964|1964 Election]]. President Johnson had been outspoken against doing so during the election and claimed that his opponent [[Barry Goldwater]] was the one that wanted to bomb North Vietnam. In another example, a memo from the Defense Department under the Johnson Administration listed the reasons for American persistence: * 70% – To avoid a humiliating U.S. defeat (to our reputation as a guarantor). * 20% – To keep [South Vietnam] (and the adjacent) territory from Chinese hands. * 10% – To permit the people [of South Vietnam] to enjoy a better, freer way of life. * ALSO – To emerge from the crisis without unacceptable taint from methods used. * NOT – To help a friend, although it would be hard to stay in if asked out.{{cite book|last=Perlstein|first=Rick|authorlink=Rick Perlstein|title=[[Nixonland: The Rise of a President and the Fracturing of America]]|year=2008|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=978-0-7432-4302-5}} Another controversy was that President Johnson sent combat troops to Vietnam by July 17, 1965, before pretending to consult his advisors on July 21–27, per the cable stating that "[[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense|Deputy Secretary of Defense]] [[Cyrus Vance]] informs McNamara that President had approved 34 Battalion Plan and will try to push through [[Reserve component of the Armed Forces of the United States|reserve]] call-up."[http://www.mtholyoke.edu/acad/intrel/pentagon4/pent6.htm Chronology]. "U.S. Ground Strategy and Force Deployments, 1965-1968," (1971). Pp. 277-604 in ''The Pentagon Papers, Gravel Edition'' Vol. 4. Boston: Beacon Press. In 1988, when that cable was declassified, it revealed "there was a continuing uncertainty as to [Johnson's] final decision, which would have to await Secretary McNamara's recommendation and the views of Congressional leaders, particularly the views of [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Richard Russell, Jr.|[Richard] Russell]]."John Burke and Fred Greenstein, ''How Presidents Test Reality: Decisions on Vietnam, 1954 and 1965''. (1989) p. 215 n. 30. Nixon's [[Solicitor General of the United States|Solicitor General]] [[Erwin N. Griswold]] later called the ''Pentagon Papers'' an example of "massive overclassification" with "no trace of a threat to the national security." The ''Pentagon Papers''' publication had little or no effect on the ongoing war because they dealt with documents written years before publication. After the release of the ''Pentagon Papers'', [[Barry Goldwater|Goldwater]] said: {{quote|During the campaign, President Johnson kept reiterating that he would never send American boys to fight in Vietnam. As I say, he knew at the time that American boys were going to be sent. In fact, I knew about ten days before the Republican Convention. You see I was being called a trigger-happy, warmonger, bomb happy, and all the time Johnson was saying, he would never send American boys, I knew damn well he would.}} Senator [[Birch Bayh]], who thought the publishing of the ''Pentagon Papers'' was justified, said: {{quote|The existence of these documents, and the fact that they said one thing and the people were led to believe something else, is a reason we have a credibility gap today, the reason people don't believe the government. This is the same thing that's been going on over the last two-and-a-half years of this administration. There is a difference between what the President says and what the government actually does, and I have confidence that they are going to make the right decision, if they have all the facts.}} ==Full release in 2011== On May 4, 2011, the National Archives and Records Administration announced that the papers would be declassified and released to the [[Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum]] in [[Yorba Linda, California]], on June 13, 2011.{{cite web| title=Pentagon Papers to be Officially Released|author=Steven Aftergood|publisher=Federation of American Scientists, Secrecy News|date=May 2011|url=https://fas.org/blog/secrecy/2011/05/pentagon_papers.html|accessdate=2011-05-13}}{{Citation|title=Nixon Presidential Historical Materials: Opening of Materials|publisher=76 FR 27092 (2011-05-10)|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2011-05-10/pdf/2011-11533.pdf}} The release date included the Nixon, Kennedy, and Johnson Libraries and the Archives office in [[College Park, Maryland]].{{cite news |title=Pentagon Papers to be declassified at last |first=Ukman |last=Jason |author2=Jaffe, Greg |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/national-security/pentagon-papers-to-be-declassified-at-last/2011/06/08/AGA0VuOH_story.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 10, 2011 |accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The full release was coordinated by the Archives's [[National Declassification Center]] (NDC) as a special project to mark the anniversary of the report.{{cite news |title=Pentagon Papers released: How they did it |first=Ed |last=O'Keefe |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/federal-eye/post/pentagon-papers-released-how-they-did-it/2011/06/13/AGpOnMTH_blog.html |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=June 13, 2011 |accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The NDC worked with the agencies having classification control over the material to prevent the [[redaction]] of the last 11 words of the ''Pentagon Papers'' that would not have been made available. It is unknown which 11 words were at issue.{{cite news| title=Finding the Secret 11 Words|first=Sam |last=Roberts|work=The New York Times|date=July 23, 2011|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/24/sunday-review/24words.html|accessdate=2012-04-18}} The Archives released each volume of the ''Pentagon Papers'' as a separate PDF file, available on their website.{{cite web |url=https://www.archives.gov/research/pentagon-papers/ |title=Pentagon Papers |author=National Archives and Records Administration |date=June 13, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zQ4nLQ7q?url=http://www.archives.gov/research/pentagon-papers/ |archivedate=June 13, 2011 |accessdate=June 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==In films and television== ===Films=== * ''[[The Pentagon Papers (film)|The Pentagon Papers]]'' (2003), directed by [[Rod Holcomb]] and Executive Produced by [[Joshua D. Maurer]], is a [[Historical drama film|historical film]] made for [[FX (TV Channel)|FX]], in association with [[Paramount Television]] and City Entertainment, about the ''Pentagon Papers'' and Daniel Ellsberg's involvement in their publication. The film represents Ellsberg's life, beginning with his work for [[RAND Corp]]. and ending with the day on which his espionage trial was declared a mistrial by a federal court judge. The film starred [[James Spader]], [[Paul Giamatti]], [[Alan Arkin]], and [[Claire Forlani]]. * ''[[The Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers]]'' (2009) is an Oscar nominated [[documentary film]], directed by [[Judith Ehrlich]] and Rick Goldsmith, that follows Ellsberg and explores the events leading up to the publication of the ''Pentagon Papers''. * {{cite AV media|title=Daniel Ellsberg: Secrets - Vietnam and the Pentagon Papers|publisher=University of California Television (UCTV) |date=August 7, 2008|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OF8nuvGyngU}} "In 1971 [[Defense Department]] analyst, former U.S. Marine company commander and anti-Communist Daniel Ellsberg leaked the ''Pentagon Papers'' to the media. In this talk, Ellsberg presents an explosive inside account of how and why he helped bring an end to the [[Vietnam War]] and [[Richard Nixon]]'s presidency. He also talks about the current potential for war with Iraq and why he feels that would be a major mistake for the United States." Series: Voices [1/2003] [Public Affairs] [Humanities] [Show ID: 7033]" * ''[[The Post (film)|The Post]]'' (2017) is a historical drama film directed and co-produced by [[Steven Spielberg]] from a script written by Liz Hannah and [[Josh Singer]] about a pair of ''The Washington Post'' employees who battle the federal government over their right to publish the ''Pentagon Papers''. The film stars [[Tom Hanks]] as [[Ben Bradlee]] and [[Meryl Streep]] as [[Katharine Graham]]. Daniel Ellsberg is played by [[Matthew Rhys]]. ===Television=== * {{cite AV media|title=The Pentagon Papers, Daniel Ellsberg and The Times|date=October 4, 2010|publisher=[[PBS]]|url= http://video.pbs.org/video/1602912290/}} "On September 13, 2010, ''The New York Times'' Community Affairs Department and POV presented a panel discussion on the ''Pentagon Papers'', Daniel Ellsberg, and the ''Times''. The conversation, featuring Daniel Ellsberg, [[Max Frankel]], former ''[[The New York Times]]'' executive editor, and [[Adam Liptak]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' Supreme Court reporter, was moderated by [[Jill Abramson]], managing editor of ''The New York Times''" and former Washington bureau chief, marking the 35th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling. {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox video game | title = Planet Coaster | image = Planet coaster box.png | developer = [[Frontier Developments]] | publisher = Frontier Developments | engine = | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = {{Video game release|WW|17 November 2016}} | genre = [[Construction and management simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | director = James Dixon | producer = {{Unbulleted list|Richard Newbold|Steve Wilkins}} | designer = Andrew Fletcher | programmer = Oscar Cooper | artist = {{Unbulleted list|John Laws|Matthew Preece|Marc Cox|Sam Denney}} | writer = | composer = {{Unbulleted list|[[Jim Guthrie (singer-songwriter)|Jim Guthrie]]|JJ Ipsen}} }}
'''''Planet Coaster''''' is a [[construction and management simulation]] [[video game]] developed and published by [[Frontier Developments]] for [[Microsoft Windows]]. It was released worldwide on 17 November 2016. Frontier had previously worked in the amusement park construction and management genre with ''[[RollerCoaster Tycoon 3]]'' (to which ''Planet Coaster'' is a [[spiritual successor]]), ''[[Thrillville]]'', ''[[Thrillville: Off the Rails]]'', and ''[[Zoo Tycoon (2013 video game)|Zoo Tycoon]]''.
There are three different modes in the game, namely Sandbox, Challenge, and Career. In the career mode, players assume the role of a theme park manager, and must complete tasks such as constructing unfinished roller coasters or hiring janitors. In Sandbox mode, players are tasked to construct their own theme park on an empty plot of land. The challenge mode is similar to the sandbox mode, but with added difficulty, as players need to take funds into account.
Originally called ''Coaster Park Tycoon'', the game was revealed on 29 January 2015 and was renamed during [[E3 2015]]. ''Planet Coaster'' is Frontier's second self-published franchise, following ''[[Elite: Dangerous]]''. Frontier organized multiple alpha and beta testings before launching in November 2016. The game was supported with free post-release [[downloadable content]] upon launch. The title received positive reviews upon release, with critics praising the game's sandbox mode and creation tools. Criticisms were mainly directed to the game's career mode. It was a commercial success, with more than 400,000 copies sold in its first month of release.
== Gameplay == [[File:Planet Coaster Guests.jpg|thumb|left|Promotional image of guests riding a [[Pirate ship (ride)|pirate ship ride]].]] ''Planet Coaster'' is a [[construction and management simulation]] video game. Similar to its spiritual predecessor, the game allows players to build different theme park rides and roller-coasters. These player-created attractions can be shared through a mechanic called "global village".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/06/16/elite-dangerous-studio-debuts-planet-coaster-theme-park-simulator/|title=Elite: Dangerous studio debuts Planet Coaster theme-park simulator (update)|first=Gavin|last=Greene|date=16 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2015|work=[[VentureBeat]]}}</ref> The game also comes with ten [[Costumed character#In theme parks, international fairs, and festivals|mascot]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Livingston|first1=Christopher|title=The Planet Coaster mascots ranked from worst to best|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-planet-coaster-mascots-ranked-from-worst-to-best/|accessdate=26 November 2016|work=PC Gamer|date=25 November 2016}}</ref>
Before starting the game, the player must create their own [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]]. Afterwards, the player is able to choose between three game modes: sandbox, challenge, and career.
Similar to Frontier's previous game, ''[[RollerCoaster Tycoon 3]]'', the Sandbox Mode enables players to construct their own theme park on an empty plot of land. In Sandbox Mode, all features and rides of the game are unlocked and your funds are unlimited. This is the mode most players use to create items (parks, coasters, scenery, etc.) and then post them to Steam's Planet Coaster Workshop.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Forward|first1=Jordan|title=The best Planet Coaster creations|url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/planet-coaster/planet-coaster-creations|accessdate=20 June 2017|work=PCGamesN|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
In the Challenge Mode, the player must construct an amusement park on an empty lot (similar to Sandbox Mode) but with limited funds and research depending on chosen difficulty—Easy, Medium, or Hard. As the player develops their park, the game presents the player with challenges that the player must accept or decline. Upon completion of a challenge, the player is given a reward such as a park rating boost or a sum of money.
In the Career Mode, the player must complete objectives such as constructing [[roller coaster]]s, achieving park ratings or hiring [[janitor]]s.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Harker|first1=Clover|title=Gamereactor UK|url=http://www.gamereactor.eu/reviews/482583/Planet+Coaster/|accessdate=23 November 2016|work=www.gamereactor.eu|date=19 November 2016}}</ref> Similar to Frontier's previous game, ''[[RollerCoaster Tycoon 3]]'', Career Mode allows players to progress by completing scenarios with objectives in different difficulties.
First unveiled at [[EGX (expo)|EGX 2016]], the game also features a dedicated mode called the "crash mode" which allows players to construct incomplete coasters and let them crash into the park's visitors.<ref name="Venture">{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/09/24/planet-coaster-announces-a-mode-dedicated-to-crashes/|title=Planet Coaster announces a mode dedicated to crashes|first=Mike|last=Minotti|work=[[VentureBeat]]|date=24 September 2016|accessdate=25 September 2016}}</ref>
On 26 April 2017, Frontier revealed the existence of several cheat codes that were previously undiscovered on their official [[Internet forum|forums]]. These included the ability to ride [[go-kart]]s and the ability for [[security guard]]s to plough through guests similarly to a [[bulldozer]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Tom|last2=Fenlon|first2=Wes|title=Planet Coaster cheat lets you drive go-karts in first person|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-cheat-lets-you-drive-go-karts-in-first-person-make-everyone-puke/|accessdate=27 April 2017|work=PC Gamer|date=26 April 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Wales|first1=Matt|title=There's a Cheat Code That Turns Planet Coaster into a Mini Racer|url=http://www.kotaku.co.uk/2017/04/26/theres-a-cheat-code-that-turns-planet-coaster-into-a-mini-racer|accessdate=27 April 2017|work=Kotaku UK|date=26 April 2017}}</ref>
== Development == [[File:Planet Coaster Art.jpg|thumb|right|Concept art of an [[Animatronics|animatronic]] [[Red coat (British Army and Royal Marines)|redcoat]].]] Before the development of ''Planet Coaster'', [[Frontier Developments]] had developed several other [[construction and management simulation]] video games, including 2004's commercial and critical success ''[[RollerCoaster Tycoon 3]]'', which sold over 10 million copies.<ref name="Poly">{{cite web|url=http://www.polygon.com/2015/6/22/8825441/planet-coaster-is-getting-ready-for-a-big-ride|title=Planet Coaster is getting ready for a big ride|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=22 June 2015|accessdate=22 June 2015}}</ref> ''Planet Coaster'' serves only as a [[spiritual successor]] to ''RollerCoaster Tycoon 3'' instead of a direct sequel, as the company considered the use of the brand ''Tycoon'' "didn’t carry the cachet anymore" due to the releases of mainly poorly-received ''Tycoon'' games in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamezone.com/news/roller-coaster-tycoon-spiritual-pc-successor-planet-coaster-announced-3417774|title=Roller Coaster Tycoon spiritual PC successor Planet Coaster announced|date=16 June 2015|accessdate=22 June 2015|work=GameZone|first=Jason |last=Lopez}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2015/06/elite-dangerous-developers-talk-to-ars-about-planet-coaster/|title=Elite: Dangerous developers talk to Ars about Planet Coaster|first=Lee|last=Hutchinson|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date=18 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref> In a December 2016 interview with [[Cambridge News]], David Walsh (the [[Chief Operating Officer]] of Frontier Developments) said that the success of ''[[Elite: Dangerous]]'' enabled the company "to bring Planet Coaster to the market, which is highly significant as it demonstrates we are not a single game company”.<ref name="CamNews">{{cite news|last1=Flitton|first1=Martin|title=Why Elite Dangerous publisher Frontier's prospects are sky-rocketing|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/business/technology/elite-dangerous-publisher-frontiers-prospects-12307142|accessdate=12 December 2016|work=cambridgenews|date=12 December 2016}}</ref> Frontier Developments spent £6 million on the game's development and an additional £1.5 million on marketing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/gaming/features/david-braben-interview-1202846009/|title=‘Jurassic World: Evolution,’ ‘Elite’ Dev on State of Gaming|first=Arthur|last=Gies|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 14, 2018|accessdate=June 30, 2018}}</ref>
The game was announced on 29 January 2015 by [[Frontier Developments]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/01/26/frontier-announces-coaster-park-tycoon-for-2016|title=Frontier Announces Coaster Park Tycoon for 2016|author=Cassidee Moser|work=[[IGN]]|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref> Originally called ''Coaster Park Tycoon'', the game was renamed into ''Planet Coaster'' on 16 June 2015 during the PC Gaming Show at [[E3 2015]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/frontier-announces-planet-coaster-with-trailer/|title=Frontier announces Planet Coaster with trailer|first=Tyler|last=Wilde|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=16 June 2015|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> Frontier Developments aimed to turn the game into the company's second self-published franchise, along with the ''[[Elite: Dangerous|Elite]]'' series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamesn.com/elite-dangerous/frontier-developments-lay-off-fifteen-staff|title=Frontier Developments lay-off fifteen staff, Coaster Park Tycoon announced|author=Matt Purslow|work=PCGamesN|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=27 March 2015}}</ref> The game uses an advanced version of Cobra Engine, which is an in-house proprietary engine developed by Frontier previously used by games like ''Elite Dangerous'' and ''RollerCoaster Tycoon 3''.<ref name="Poly"/> Features confirmed for the game include a hybrid spline/piece-by-piece coaster builder, modular structure building, a voxel terrain editor among others detailed through Q&A's and "Dev Diaries."<ref name=Sims>{{cite news|last1=Developments|first1=Frontier|title=How Planet Coaster takes SIM gaming to exciting new levels of realism (Paid content by Frontier Developments)|url=http://mashable.com/2016/11/11/planet-coaster-psychology/#M1QPoNr2pkqp|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=Mashable|date=11 November 2016}}</ref> On the second live stream, the release date of the alpha was announced. Released on 22 March 2016, the alpha emphasized on modular building and paths. The alpha contained two themes: "Planet Coaster" and "Pirate". Although disabled by default, Coaster Building was included in the first alpha through a cheat code.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tucker|first1=Jake|title=Planet Coaster Reinvents The Theme Park Genre|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/03/21/planet-coaster-hands-on/|website=Rock Paper Shotgun|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref>
On 24 May 2016, Frontier released the second alpha build. This build included finances, terrain tools, improved path building, and the official release of a coaster builder.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wales|first1=Matt|title=Planet Coaster's Alpha 2 Arrives with Landscaping, VFX and Sexy Paths|url=http://www.kotaku.co.uk/2016/05/24/planet-coasters-alpha-2-arrives-with-landscaping-vfx-and-sexy-paths|accessdate=26 May 2016|work=Kotaku UK|date=24 May 2016}}</ref> Also, on 25 August, Frontier discontinued further alpha purchases.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Purslow|first1=Matt|title=Planet Coaster will require Steam and use the Workshop for community creations|url=http://www.pcgamesn.com/planet-coaster/planet-coaster-steam-workshop|accessdate=13 August 2016|date=26 July 2016}}</ref> On 24 September, Frontier announced at [[EGX (expo)|EGX 2016]] that players who had pre-ordered the "Thrillseeker Edition" would be able to test the game that October.<ref name=Venture/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Doctor|first1=V|title=‘Planet Coaster’ Crash Mode Trailer, News & Update: What Happens When a Roller Coaster Goes Off The Rails?|url=http://www.gamenguide.com/articles/49737/20160927/planet-coaster-crash-mode-trailer-news-update-what-happens-when-a-roller-coaster-goes-off-the-rails.htm|accessdate=28 September 2016|date=27 September 2016}}</ref> At [[Gamescom#2016|Gamescom 2016]], Frontier announced that the game would be released on 17 November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-08-17-planet-coaster-out-this-november|title=Planet Coaster out this November|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=17 August 2016|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> The game was released with [[Denuvo]]'s [[anti-tamper software|anti-tamper technology]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Planet Coaster z wymaganiami sprzętowymi i Denuvo|url=http://www.gry-online.pl/S013.asp?ID=100016|accessdate=9 September 2016|date=26 August 2016|language=pl-PL}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Saed|first1=Sherif|title=Dishonored 2 Steam page reveals the use of Denuvo DRM|url=https://www.vg247.com/2016/11/08/dishonored-2-steam-page-reveals-the-use-of-denuvo-drm/|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=VG247.com|date=8 November 2016}}</ref>
To record the audio for the game, sound designer Watson Wu took over the [[Holiday World & Splashin' Safari]] theme park in [[Santa Claus, Indiana]] to record the sounds of various attractions.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Paget|first1=Mat|title=To record Planet Coaster's audio, a sound designer took over an entire theme park|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/to-record-planet-coasters-audio-a-sound-designer-took-over-an-entire-theme-park/|accessdate=21 November 2016|work=pcgamer|date=20 November 2016}}</ref> Guests in the park and park staff speak their own fictional language, known as "Planco".<ref name=Sims/><ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Connor|first1=Alice|title=Whooooo! Planet Coaster Rolling Out In November|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2016/08/17/when-does-planet-coaster-come-out/|accessdate=18 November 2016|work=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|date=17 August 2016}}</ref> According to James Stant, Frontier's senior audio designer, the language contains about 7,000 words.<ref name=Sound/> After the game's release, Frontier Developments released an official Planco dictionary.<ref name=Sound>{{cite news|last1=Stant|first1=James|title=Game Design Deep Dive: Creating a new language for Planet Coaster|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/300997/Game_Design_Deep_Dive_Creating_a_new_language_for_Planet_Coaster.php|accessdate=22 July 2017|work=[[Gamasutra]]|date=13 July 2017|language=en}}</ref>
=== Soundtrack === ''Planet Coaster'' features a [[dynamic music|dynamic soundtrack]] composed by [[Jim Guthrie (singer-songwriter)|Jim Guthrie]] and JJ Ipsen, released under the album titled ''You, Me & Gravity: The Music of Planet Coaster''.<ref>{{cite |title=Jim Guthrie & JJ Ipsen present You, Me & Gravity: The Music of Planet Coaster|url=http://ymlp.com/zRKR2A|accessdate=12 December 2016|}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Slingerland|first1=Calum|title=Jim Guthrie & JJ Ipsen to Release Score for 'Planet Coaster' Videogame|url=http://exclaim.ca/music/article/jim_guthrie_and_jj_ipsen_team_up_to_score_planet_coaster_videogame|accessdate=19 October 2016|date=18 October 2016}}</ref> Additionally, players may upload their own sound files to use in their parks.
=== Downloadable content === On 21 July 2017, Frontier launched paid DLC for the game featuring props inspired by ''[[Back to the Future (franchise)|Back to the Future]]'', ''[[Knight Rider (franchise)|Knight Rider]]'', and ''[[The Munsters]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bishop|first1=Sam|title=Gamereactor UK|url=https://www.gamereactor.eu/news/575043/Planet+Coaster+gets+new+film-themed+DLCs/|accessdate=21 July 2017|work=Gamereactor|date=21 July 2017}}</ref>
In August 2017, Frontier partnered with the [[Cedar Point]] amusement park to provide an in-game version of the park's upcoming [[Steel Vengeance (roller coaster)|Steel Vengeance]] roller coaster before the ride officially opened in 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://venturebeat.com/2017/08/16/cedar-points-next-thrill-ride-debuts-in-planet-coaster/ | title = Cedar Point’s next thrill ride debuts in Planet Coaster | first = Mike | last = Minotti | date = August 16, 2017 | accessdate = August 16, 2017 | work = [[Venture Beat]] }}</ref>
On 21 September 2018, Frontier announced the "Thememaker's Toolkit". This toolkit will enable players to export custom 3D models into Planet Coaster itself. This will be released on the 20th of November.<ref>{{cite news |last1=van Miltenburg |first1=Olaf |title=Planet Coaster krijgt een Thememaker's Toolkit |url=https://tweakers.net/nieuws/143671/planet-coaster-krijgt-een-thememakers-toolkit.html |accessdate=22 September 2018 |work=Tweakers |date=21 September 2018 |language=nl-NL}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="width: 100%;" !style="width: 15%;height:50px;"|Name !style="width: 15%;"|Release date !Description |- |'''''Winter Update''''' |15 December 2016 |The "Winter Update" added new rides, blueprints, stores, and staff features.<ref name=Contest>{{cite news|last1=Plunkett|first1=Luke|title=Planet Coaster Just Got A Huge Free Update|url=http://kotaku.com/planet-coaster-just-got-a-huge-free-update-1790163089|accessdate=16 December 2016|work=Kotaku|date=15 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Chalk|first1=Andy|title=Free Planet Coaster Winter Update adds rides, blueprints, and Cosmic Cow Ice Cream|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/free-planet-coaster-winter-update-adds-rides-blueprints-and-the-cosmic-cow/|accessdate=16 December 2016|work=pcgamer|date=15 December 2016}}</ref> One of the newly added rides, the "Collider", was determined by a community vote.<ref name=Contest/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Stougie|first1=Leon|title=Planet Coaster nieuws: Holiday Update voor Planet Coaster laat spelers een gratis nieuwe attractie kiezen|url=https://www.gamersnet.nl/nieuws/201611/holiday_update_voor_planet_coaster_laat_spelers_een_gratis_nieuwe_attractie_kiezen/|accessdate=23 November 2016|work=GamersNET|date=22 November 2016|language=nl}}</ref> |- |'''''Spring Update''''' |April 2017 |The "Spring Update" added new rides and a crime system.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Pereira|first1=Chris|title=Planet Coaster's Free Spring Update Brings Crime, New Rides, And More|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/planet-coasters-free-spring-update-brings-crime-ne/1100-6448669/|accessdate=13 June 2017|work=GameSpot|date=13 March 2017}}</ref> The Spring Update was later released in April 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ferrera|first1=Jessica|title='Planet Coaster' Spring Update 1.2 Brings New Roller Coasters, Rides and More Contents for Free|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/planet-coaster-spring-update-1-2-players-get-new-roller-coasters-rides-and-more-contents-for-free-180242/|accessdate=13 June 2017|work=[[The Christian Post]]|date=16 April 2017|language=en}}</ref> |- |'''''Summer Update''''' |27 June 2017 |The "Summer Update" added the ability to create [[Fireworks|firework shows]], such as for the [[Independence Day (United States)|American Independence Day]], [[New Year's Day]], and [[Bonfire Night]]. Furthermore, the fireworks can be triggered by other events in the park and can be synced to custom music.<ref name="Fireworks"/> The summer update also added the ability to add customizable images and video into the game.<ref name="Fireworks">{{cite news|last1=Faller|first1=Patrick|title=Planet Coaster's Free Summer Update Adds Fireworks, More Customization, And New Rides|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/planet-coasters-free-summer-update-adds-fireworks-/1100-6451220/|accessdate=27 June 2017|work=GameSpot|date=27 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnelly|first1=Joe|title=Planet Coaster to add new rides, player-operated fireworks in free summer update|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-to-add-new-rides-player-operated-fireworks-in-free-summer-update/|accessdate=17 June 2017|work=pcgamer|date=14 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> |- |'''''Spooky Pack''''' |25 September 2017 |The "Spooky Pack" included over 200 new building and scenery pieces as well as two new tracked ride types. The first ride type is the Huntsman, a trackless multi-motion dark ride vehicle. The second ride type in this pack is the Hoax, a free-spinning haunted house ride with the smallest track pieces in the game. The final addition is a new entertainer called "King Ghoster," a character dressed as a ghost that "glows in the dark" with the same face as King Coaster.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnelly|first1=Joe|title=Planet Coaster unveils Halloween-themed Spooky Pack with new rides and scenery|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-unveils-halloween-themed-spooky-pack-with-new-rides-and-scenery/|accessdate=24 December 2017|work=PC Gamer|date=25 September 2017|language=en}}</ref> |- |'''''Anniversary Update''''' |22 November 2017 |The free Anniversary update included several new rides and roller coasters in addition to picnic benches and a custom scenario editor - other smaller features allow for interchangeable coaster cars and relaxed track restrictions. More management features were also introduced including more control over vendors and staff rooms for tired employees.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chalk|first1=Andy|title=Planet Coaster Anniversary Update adds a scenario editor and new rides later this month|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-anniversary-update-adds-a-scenario-editor-and-new-rides-later-this-month/|accessdate=24 December 2017|work=pcgamer|date=6 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> |- |'''''Adventure Pack''''' |18 December 2017 |The "Adventure Pack" is a paid DLC pack that includes new water boat rides, a swinging mine train roller coaster and 320 new scenery and building pieces in addition to a new entertainer "Renee Feu".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnelly|first1=Joe|title=Planet Coaster launches Adventure Pack update with hundreds of new items|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-launches-adventure-pack-update-with-hundreds-of-new-items/|accessdate=24 December 2017|work=PC Gamer|date=18 December 2017|language=en}}</ref> |- |'''''Studios Pack''''' |27 March 2018 |The Studios Pack is a paid DLC pack inspired by movie studio theme parks such as Disney's Hollywood Studios and Universal Studios. This pack includes new scenery, animatronics and 3 dark ride systems. This was released alongside a free update containing hotels, glass walls and path tunneling.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnelly|first1=Joe|title=Planet Coaster rolls out Hollywood-inspired Studios Pack|url=https://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-rolls-out-hollywood-inspired-studios-pack/|accessdate=1 April 2018|work=PC Gamer|date=28 March 2018|language=en}}</ref> |- |<strong><em>Vintage Pack</em></strong> |10 July 2018 |The Vintage Pack is a paid DLC pack inspired by classic amusement parks. It includes new coasters, rides, scenery and audio.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vg247.com/2018/07/03/planet-coaster-vintage-pack-launches-july-10/|title=Planet Coaster Vintage Pack recreates the golden age of amusement parks - VG247|date=2018-07-03|work=VG247|access-date=2018-07-07|language=en-US}}</ref>This was released alongside a free update containing a wild mouse coaster, vending machines, camera effects, scenery grouping, and custom staff uniform coloring.<ref>https://steamcommunity.com/games/493340/announcements/detail/1679162920025522396</ref> |- |'''World's Fair Pack''' |16 October 2018 |The World's Fair Pack is a paid DLC pack introduction theming elements inspired by ten different countries. It includes new coasters, a transport ride and scenery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2018-10-09-planet-coaster-gets-some-international-flair-in-the-upcoming-worlds-fair-expansion|title=Planet Coaster gets some international flair in its upcoming World's Fair expansion|last=Wales|first=Matt|date=2018-10-09|work=Eurogamer.net|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref> |- |}
== Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC = 84/100<ref name="MetaCritic">{{cite news|title=Planet Coaster|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/planet-coaster|accessdate=26 November 2016|work=Metacritic}}</ref> | Destruct = 7.5/10<ref name="Destructoid">{{cite news|last1=Hancock|first1=Patrick|title=Review: Planet Coaster|url=https://www.destructoid.com/review-planet-coaster-404044.phtml|accessdate=24 December 2016|work=Destructoid|date=21 December 2016}}</ref> | Edge = 8/10<ref name=Edge>{{cite journal|title=Planet Coaster|journal=Edge|issue=January 2017|page=116}}</ref> | GameRev = {{Rating|4.5|5}}<ref name=Rev>{{cite news|last1=Leack|first1=Jonathan|title=Planet Coaster Review|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/planet-coaster|accessdate=6 December 2016|work=www.gamerevolution.com|date=17 November 2016}}</ref> | GI = 8.25/10<ref name="GI">{{cite news|last1=Reeves|first1=Ben|title=Planet Coaster Review – A Walk In The Theme Park|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/planet_coaster_simulation_evolved/b/pc/archive/2016/11/22/planet-coaster-game-informer-review.aspx|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=Game Informer|date=22 November 2016}}</ref> | GSpot = 9/10<ref name="GSpot">{{cite news|last1=Tran|first1=Edmond|title=Planet Coaster Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/planet-coaster-review/1900-6416582/|accessdate=5 December 2016|work=GameSpot|date=5 December 2016}}</ref> | IGN = 8.5/10<ref name="IGN">{{cite news|last1=Hafer|first1=T. J.|title=Planet Coaster Review|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/11/23/planet-coaster-review|accessdate=24 November 2016|work=IGN|date=23 November 2016}}</ref> | PCGUS = 75/100<ref name="PCGReview">{{cite news|last1=Macgregor|first1=Jody|title=Planet Coaster review|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-review/|accessdate=22 November 2016|work=pcgamer|date=17 November 2016}}</ref> }}
=== Pre-release === The game was met with praise upon release of the alpha. Andy Kelly of ''[[PC Gamer]]'' commented that Frontier was "off to a tremendous start", adding that creating buildings with the creation tools hinted at "immense possibilities".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kelly|first1=Andy|title=Planet Coaster: hands-on with Frontier's theme park sim|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/planet-coaster-we-play-frontiers-theme-park-sim/|website=PC Gamer|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> However, Mark Walton of ''[[Ars Technica]]'' noted several small flaws including the "hard to navigate" menus and the lack of custom built roller coasters.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walton|first1=Mark|title=Planet Coaster: A theme park sim so good its developers forgot to develop it|url=http://arstechnica.co.uk/gaming/2016/03/planet-coaster-theme-park-sim-alpha-preview/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=27 March 2016}}</ref> On 27 April 2016, about a month after the release of the alpha, Frontier announced that ''Planet Coaster'' had grossed nearly two million dollars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Walker|first1=Alex|title=Planet Coaster Has Nearly Made $2 Million Already|url=http://www.kotaku.com.au/2016/04/planet-coaster-has-nearly-made-2-million-already/|website=www.kotaku.com.au|accessdate=29 April 2016}}</ref>
===Release=== {{expand section|date=January 2017}} Matt Wales of ''[[Eurogamer]]'' recommended the game, concluding that the game is "the finest simulator yet".<ref name="EuroG">{{cite news|last1=Wales|first1=Matt|title=Planet Coaster review|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-11-20-planet-coaster-review|accessdate=21 November 2016|work=Eurogamer|date=21 November 2016|language=en-UK}}</ref> Meanwhile, Ben Reeves of ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised the game for its creative mode but criticized the game's career mode, referring it to as "boring" and "tedious".<ref name="GI"/> TJ Hafer of ''[[IGN]]'' compared the game's integration of [[Steam Workshop]] to ''[[Minecraft]]'' and ''[[Second Life]]''.<ref name="IGN"/> Edmond Tran of ''[[GameSpot]]'' praised the game for its accessible creative tools and for its evocative tone.<ref name="GSpot"/> Jonathan Leack of [[Game Revolution]] claimed that the game "resurrected the [theme park simulation] genre".<ref name=Rev/> In a critical review of the game, Jody Macgregor of ''[[PC Gamer]]'' praised the game's challenge mode but criticized the game for not innovating enough from ''[[RollerCoaster Tycoon 3]]''. The original score (70/100) was retracted due to miscommunication between Frontier Developments and ''PC Gamer'' with the game version they received; its reevaluated score is 75/100.<ref name="PCGReview"/> Patrick Hancock of [[Destructoid]] noted that the game suffers [[frame rate]] issues in larger parks.<ref name="Destructoid"/> Furthermore, ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'' noted that the game's "fiddly" camera makes some actions harder.<ref name=Edge/>
===Sales=== Upon release, the game topped the [[Steam (software)|Steam]] "top sellers" charts.<ref name="CamNews"/> The game sold over 400,000 copies in the first month of its release.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flitton|first1=Martin|title=Rocketing sales of Planet Coaster give Frontier a big revenue bump|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/business/technology/popularity-planet-coaster-gives-frontier-12462641|accessdate=22 January 2017|work=cambridgenews|date=16 January 2017}}</ref> Despite being released later in the year, ''Planet Coaster'' was featured on Steam's "Top 100 Best Sellers of 2016" chart as a "silver tier" title.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Mike|title=GTA 5 and Civilization 6 Top Steam Best-Sellers of 2016|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/gta-5-and-civilization-6-top-steam-best-sellers-of-2016|accessdate=7 January 2017|work=USgamer|date=3 January 2017}}</ref> In August 2017, the game has sold over one million copies.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Phillips|first1=Tom|title=Planet Coaster soars past one million sales|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-08-15-planet-coaster-soars-past-million-sales|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=15 August 2017}}</ref> In July 2018, a leak in [[Valve Corporation|Valve’s]] [[Application programming interface|API]] revealed that over 1.68 million Steam users owned Planet Coaster.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Orland |first1=Kyle |title=Valve leaks Steam game player counts; we have the numbers |url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2018/07/steam-data-leak-reveals-precise-player-count-for-thousands-of-games/2/ |accessdate=6 July 2018 |work=Ars Technica |date=6 July 2018 |language=en-us}}</ref>
==Accolades== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Award !! Category !! Result !! Ref |- | rowspan="5" style="text-align:center;"| 2017 | [[13th British Academy Games Awards]] | British Game | {{nom}} | <ref name="bafta noms">{{cite web |url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/04/07/bafta-games-awards-2017-winners-revealed | title =Bafta Games Awards 2017 Winners Revealed|first = Joe| last = Skrebels | date = 7 April 2017 | accessdate = 12 May 2017 | work = [[IGN]] }}</ref> |- | rowspan="4" | [[Develop (magazine)|Develop Industry Excellence Awards]] | Animation | {{nom}} | rowspan="4" | <ref>{{cite news|last1=Dunning|first1=Jason|title=Develop Awards 2017 Winners: Guerrilla Games Takes Home Studio of the Year|url=http://www.playstationlifestyle.net/2017/07/13/develop-awards-2017-winners-guerrilla-games-takes-home-studio-year/|accessdate=21 July 2017|work=Playstation Lifestyle|date=13 July 2017}}</ref> |- | Music Design | {{nom}} |- | New Games IP | {{nom}} |- | Sound Design | {{nom}} |- |}
